core package

Submodules

core.gamma module

gamma.py

Defines the class Gamma, representing a gamma pulse in the simulation. This class provides geometric properties and methods to change its dimensions and position. Also includes matplotlib integration through patches.

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.gamma.Gamma(x_pos: float, pulse_length: float, height: float, off_axis_dist: float, facecolor=(0, 0, 1, 0.5), edgecolor=(1, 0, 0), linewidth=2)[source]

Bases: object

Gamma pulse parameters and axes object

Attributes:

x_pos (float): x-coordinate of gamma pulse (left edge of rectangle) (mm) pulse_length (float): length of gamma pulse (mm) height (float): height of gamma pulse in 2D, for an azimuthal angle of 0,

this corresponds to the radius (mm)

off_axis_dist (float): perpendicular distance from bottom of gamma pulse

to x-ray source when directly over head (mm)

facecolor (tuple, optional): face colour of axes object. Defaults to (0, 0, 1, 0.5). edgecolor (tuple, optional): edge colour of axes object. Defaults to (1, 0, 0). linewidth (int, optional): line width of axes object. Defaults to 2.

Methods:

get_bounds() -> list: returns the coordinates of the 4 corners of the gamma pulse move(dx: float): moves the gamma pulse by distance dx set_xpos(new_xpos: float): changes gamma pulse’s x-position set_height(new_height: float): changes the height/radius of the gamma pulse

get_bounds()[source]

Coordinates of the gamma pulse boundaries

Returns:

list: coordinates of the 4 corners of the gamma pulse [xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax]

get_gamma_axes_obj() → float[source]

Access method for the gamma axes object

Returns:

matplotlib.patches.Rectangle: Axes object for gamma pulse

float: axial displacement (mm)

Access method for pulse length

Returns:

float: length of pulse (mm)

float: initial x-coordinate (mm)

Args:

new_x_pos (float): x coordinate to move to

core.simulation module

simulation.py

Defines the class simulation, which simulates the interaction between the Xray bath and Gamma pulse using a Monte Carlo method. Performs basic simulation tasks such as predicting hits, detecting hits, and plotting. Designed as a subclass to more in-depth simulation tasks such as visualisation and estimating positron pairs produced

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.simulation.Simulation(xray_bath: Xray, gamma_pulse: Gamma)[source]

Bases: object

Simulation of X-ray bath and gamma pulse interactions (hits)

Attributes:

xray_bath (Xray): Xray object instance gamma_pulse (Gamma): Gamma object instance

Methods:
get_overlap_coords(coords: list, beam_bounds: list) -> int, numpy.ndarray:

finds coordinates of Xrays inside the gamma pulse beam bounds

find_hits(self, eff_height = None, eff_d = None) -> int, list[list[float]]

find_hits(eff_height: float = None, eff_d: float = None) → tuple[source]

Calculate hits using X-ray seed coordinates Check future position and see if registers a hit

Args:
eff_height (float, optional): effective height if on an off-azimuthal position.

Defaults to None

eff_d (float, optional): effective off-axis displacement. Defaults to None

Returns:
tuple (float, list[list[float]]): Tuple containing:

  • number of ovelaps

  • coordinates of overlaps in the form [time, x, y, angle]

Get coordinates of overlapping points of x-ray and gamma pulses

Args:

coords (list): Coordinates of x-ray pulse points beam_bounds (list): Boundaries of gamma pulse [xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax]

Returns:

core.xray module

xray.py

Defines the class Xray, representing the Xray bath in the simulation. Does so by sampling a radially-uniform, gaussian travelling profile. This class provides attributes and methods for sampling, generating, and moving the sampled ‘Xray photons’. Designed to be subclassed by other distribution types for Xray modelling such as ‘XrayLambertian’ and ‘XrayLine’

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.xray.Xray(fwhm: float, rotation=0, n_samples_angular=400, n_samples=10)[source]

Bases: object

Coordinates and distribution of the X-ray bath

Attributes:

fwhm (float): Full-Width-Half-Maximum of the X-ray distribution (mm) Variance (float): Variance of the X-ray distribution (mm^2)

Methods:
gen_xray_seed(mean: float, variance: float, **kwargs: float) -> numpy.ndarray:

Generates Xray coordinates sampled from a radially-uniform, gaussian profile.

move_xrays(t: float): moves Xray coordinates to their position at time t. resample(phi: unused): Generates a new set of Xray coordinates get_n_samples_total() -> int: Returns the total number of Xray coordinates generated

gen_xray_seed(mean, variance, **kwargs) → list[source]

Generates distribution of X ray pulse in 2D

Args:

mean (float): mean of distribution, radial position (m) variance (float): variance of x-ray distribution (mm^2) **kwargs: optional

rotation (float, optional): rotation of the Xray source

or the kapton tape angle (rad). Defaults to 0

n_samples_angular (int, optional): Number of angles to sample. Defaults to 400 n_samples (int, optional): Number of samples per angle. Defaults to 10.

Returns:

numpy.ndarray[list[float]]: coordinates for distribution points in form [x, y, angle] | the angle is to the x-axis in the plane of the gamma pulse’s motion

core.xray_lambertian module

xray_lambertian.py

Defines the XrayLambertian class which inherits from the Xray class. Represents a Lambertian disturibution of Xrays, I = I0cosx. This class redefines the Xray coordinate generation and method for obtaining the total number of samples taken.

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.xray_lambertian.XrayLambertian(fwhm: float, rotation=0, n_samples_angular=400, n_samples=10)[source]

Bases: Xray

Coordinates and distribution of the X-ray bath Inherits from the Xray bath class Uses a lambertian distribution for points instead

Overridden methods:
gen_xray_seed(mean: float, variance: float, **kwargs: float) -> numpy.ndarray:

Generates Xray coordinates sampled from a lambertian, gaussian profile.

get_n_samples_total() -> int: Returns the total number of Xray coordinates generated

appropriate for a lambertian distribution.

gen_xray_seed(mean: float, variance: float, **kwargs)[source]

Generates a lambertian distribution of X ray pulse in 2D

Args:

mean (float): mean of distribution, radial position (m) variance (float): variance of x-ray distribution (mm^2) **kwargs: optional

rotation (float, optional): rotation of the Xray source

or the kapton tape angle (rad). Defaults to 0

n_samples_angular (int, optional): Number of angles to sample. Defaults to 400 n_samples (int, optional): Number of samples per angle. Defaults to 10. get_n_lambert (bool, optional): If True, returns the number of generated

samples along with the coordinates. Defaults to False.

Returns:

np.ndarray[list[float]]: list of coordinates for distribution points int (conditional): number of samples taken

get_n_samples_total() → int[source]

Returns:

int: total number of xray coordinates generated

core.xray_lambertian_Ge module

xray_lambertian.py

Defines a Lambertian Xray source Characteristic of a Germanium source. cos0.4 x (Cary Colgan PhD)

core.xray_line module

xrayline.py

Defines the XrayLine class which inherits from the XrayLambertian class. Represents a line source’s Xray emissions, done so by placing multiple point-Lambertian sources along its length.

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.xray_line.XrayLine(fwhm: float, line_length: float, rotation=0, n_samples_angular=400, n_samples=10, n_line_samples=10)[source]

Bases: XrayLambertian

Generates a line source by setting up an array of lambertian point sources

This class extends ‘XrayLambertian’ Attributes:

line_length (float): Total physical length of the X-ray line source (mm). n_line_samples (int): Number of discrete Lambertian emitters along the line. xray_coords (list): 2D array of sampled ray coordinates (overridden). n_samples_total (int): Total number of Xray photons generated (overridden).

Overridden Methods:

  • resample(azimuthal_angle: float): Resamples Xrays based on azimuthal orientation.

  • get_n_samples_total() -> int: Returns total number of Xrays photons generated.

New Methods:
  • gen_xray_seed_line(azimuthal_angle: float) -> list, int:

    Initializes the Xray coordinates by seeding each point source along the line.

gen_xray_seed_line(phi=0, get_total_samples=False)[source]

Generates xray coordinates for a line source

Returns:

list: array of line source generated xray coordinates

get_line_length() → float[source]

Access method for line_length

Returns:

float: length of line source

get_n_line_samples() → int[source]

Access method for number of line samples

Returns:

int: number of line samples

get_n_samples_total() → int[source]

Access method for total n_samples_total

Returns:

int: Number of Xray coordinates generated

resample(phi=None)[source]

Resamples x-ray distribution

core.xray_line_twave module

xrayline.py

Defines the XrayTwave class which inherits from the XrayLine class. Represents a line source’s Xray emissions, done so by placing multiple point-Lambertian sources along its length. And the sources are ignited by a travelling wave.

Timothy Chew 1/8/25

class core.xray_line_twave.XrayTwave(fwhm, line_length, rotation=0, n_samples_angular=400, n_samples=10, n_line_samples=10, wave_speed=1)[source]

Bases: XrayLine

Generates a line source by setting up an array of lambertian point sources which are ignited by a travelling wave

This class extends ‘Xrayline’ Attributes:

  • wave_speed (float, optional): speed of the travelling wave igniting the xray source

    (natural units). Defaults to 1.

Overridden Methods:
  • gen_xray_seed_line(azimuthal_angle: float) -> list, int:

    Initializes the Xray coordinates by seeding each point source along the line and displacing their mean to for a travelling wave with velocity c.

gen_xray_seed_line(phi=0, get_total_samples=False)[source]

Generates xray coordinates for a line source

Returns:

list: array of line source generated xray coordinates

get_wave_speed()[source]

Access method for wave_speed

Returns:

float: travelling wave velocity (ms^-1)
